data.title: Folklore, Myth, and Fairy tale
data.text:
Special Issue: Oral Tradition 4.1/2 (Jan.-May 1989): Arabic Oral Traditions. [Includes articles on the Koran, Arabian Nights, epic tradition, and music.]

Special Issue: Oral Tradition 2.2/3 (May-Oct. 1987): Hispanic Balladry. [Includes Spanish, Canary, Portuguese, Brazilian, and Judeo-Spanish ballads; mentions children as part of the audience for them.]

Special Issue: Scandinavian Studies 61.4 (Autumn 1989): Nordic Narrative Folklore, ed. John Lindow. [Lindow's introduction, 299-303, surveys folklore research in Scandinavia from its beginnings.]

1505. Algaier, Charles J. "Ancient Thai Teases." Linguistics of the Tibeto-Burman Area 10.1 (Spring 1987): 182-85. [The play and teasing speech of Thai children.] MLA

1506. Barber, Giles. "'Malbrouck s'en va-t-en guerre' or, How History Reaches the Nursery." Avery 135-63. [An overview of the genesis of some popular French songs for children followed by the history of this one. Stresses the remoteness of the song from its historical prototype and its amazing international popularity in the 1780s. A catchy tune and "dramatic and processional content" guaranteed its success with children.]

1507. Beck, Brenda E.F. et al. Folktales of India. Chicago: U of Chicago P, 1987. xxxi + 357 p. Rev. David Shulman, Journal of American Folklore 102.405 (July-Sept 1989): 345-47. [A collaborative venture in the works since 1964. Some translations show more sensitivity to the oral texts than some others, which read like condensations. Nevertheless, a fine collection worth waiting for.]

1508. Bell, Suzanne Comer. "'Epaminondas': The African-American Silly Son." Southern Folklore 46.3 (1989): 221-39. [Compares the tale with the distant European variants (Tale type 1696) and concludes that the tale belongs among African-American folktales, may well have been circulated among slaves, and probably had African roots since it forms part of the Ghanaian oral tradition. Bell seems unaware that the story has been current as a children's book for many years.]

1509. Bjurstrom, C.G., comp. French Folktales. Trans. Royall Tyler. Pantheon Fairy Tale and Folklore Library. New York: Pantheon, 1989. 484 p, illus. Rev. Robin McKinley, New York Times Book Review, 24 Dec 1989: 25. [Tales are chosen from 1009 stories collected by the early 20th cen. French folklorist Henri Pourrat in the Auvergne, range from the familiar to the unfamiliar, and are thick with local and country lore. Beautifully translated; not to be missed.]

1510. Bordier, René. "Une poésie féminine: les berceuses." [Feminine poetry: lullabies]. Notre Librairie 97 (April-May 1989): 49-53. [The most beautiful songs of central Africa are those lullabies where the mother or her surrogate expresses all her love for the young child. The lullabies also provide a record of the culture. Gives some lullabies in African languages with French translations.]

1511. Bottigheimer, Ruth B., ed. Fairy Tales and Society: Illusion, Allusion and Paradigm. Philadelphia: U of Pennsylvania P, 1986. Rev. Hamida Bosmajian, "The Fairy Tale Controversy: Oral Tradition, Texts, 'the Text'," CLAQ 14.3:150-151. [Reworkings of presentations at the Princeton 1984 conference on the subject. Covers the interpretations of fairy tales and society, an assessment of current research on fairy tales, and an introduction to current German research which includes all the current "isms".] Essay rev. Elizabeth Keyser, "Feminist Revisions: Frauds on the Fairies?" CL 17 (1989): 156-70. [Introductory essay by Lutz Röhrich seems to recognize how feminist explorations of fairy tale can break new ground and endanger the old.]

1512. Bryant, Sylvia. "Reconstructing Oedipus Through 'Beauty and the Beast.'" Criticism 31.4 (Fall 1989); 439-53. [Discusses Angela Carter's 2 versions of Beauty and the Beast in The Bloody Chamber, Jean Cocteau's film La Belle et La Bête, and the TV series "Beauty and the Beast" under the rubric of the Oedipal myth.]

1513. Butler, Francelia. Skipping Around the World: The Ritual Nature of Folk Rhymes. Hamden, CT: Library Professional Publications, 1989. Hard and Paper. [Forward by Stephen Spender. Probably the first international study of skipping rhymes; 350 arranged by category...
